The project would achieve its objective through: (a) improving research organization and management; (b) supporting priority research programs on promising areas; (c) strengthening client orientation; and (d) improving research resource allocation. Project components: The project would have three components: (a) Research organization and management (US$13.99 million), focusing on institutional policy reforms and strengthening research planning in BARC and ARls; (b) Priority Research (US$40.57 million) in the ARIs on crops, fisheries, livestock and forestry and with other institutions through contract research managed by BARC; and (c) Participatory Farming Systems (US$4.56) research linkages to improve technology transfer. The project would finance civil works, local and imported goods and equipment (farm, office, laboratory, and vehicles), contract research, technical assistance, training, labor, and incremental staff and operating costs. Costs and financing plan: Total project costs are estimated at US$59.1 million. Project baseline costs are estimated at US$52.9 million; physical contingencies are estimated to be US$ 2.2 million and price contingencies are estimated to be US$ 4.0 million. An IDA credit would provide US$50.0 million and the Government of Bangladesh would provide US$9.1 million. Of the total project cost, US$46.2 million would be for investment and US$12.9 would be for incremental recurrent costs. Benefits: The project would assist in the generation of more productive agricultural (crops, livestock, fisheries, and forestry) technology. Support to research linkages and adaptation would lead to stronger linkages with farmers, extension services and NGOs, and promote the development of adoptable technology and a stronger foundation for the

 BANGLADESH AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH MANAGEMENT PROJECT 1. THE AGRICULTURAL SECTOR A. Introduction 1.1 Bangladesh is one of the poorest countries in the world, with an average income of US$220 in 1993 and with about half its population living in poverty. Agriculture (crops, livestock, fisheries and forestry) is vital in the economy, accounting for about 30 percent of GDP, 65 percent of employment and 17 percent of commodity export earnings. Economic growth sufficient to relieve poverty requires, therefore, significant growth in agricultural output and productivity or a massive shift of people out of agriculture into other sectors. 1.2 Raising agricultural output confronts several challenges. The first is to grow from a resource base that is already very intensively used. The projected 1996 population of about 123 million people lives on 14.8 million hectares (ha), making Bangladesh the most densely populated country in the world. Arable land covers 8.1 million ha--or roughly 55 percent of the national area--with another 1.9 million ha in forest or woodland, so there is no possibility to grow by cultivating more land. Of the national total of roughly 19 million households, about 14 million are farm households and 7.7 million are rural landless; the landless, and those operating holdings of less than 0.5 hectares (ha), have little or no asset base in which to invest. Lastly, while expansion of irrigation and fertilizer use have contributed to recent growth, additional irrigable land is becoming scarcer, the costs of new irrigation are expected to rise, and the marginal returns to fertilizer have fallen from the levels of the mid-1980s. Though significant potential for exploitation of inexpensive groundwater exists, the cheapest irrigation opportunities have already been used. 1.3 The second challenge is water control. While rainfall and surface waters are usually abundant, recurrent droughts and floods make it difficult to sustain growth. Because production will always be subject to the onset and intensity of the monsoons and to the severity of the dry season, costly investments in irrigation, drainage, and flood control are needed to manage water, maintain coastlines and river banks against erosion, to prevent salt water incursion and to protect inland fisheries from disruption by flood control and drainage activities. 1.4 The third challenge is the heterogeneity of agriculture. Arable land has been classified into 30 agro-ecological zones (AEZs) and 80 subzones according to soil type, land shape, probability of flooding, length of growing season, and temperature. Although temperatures are generally suitable for crop production throughout the year, distinct hot, warm and cool seasons make farm management complex in terms of the appropriate mix of crops, livestock, forestry, aquatic species, and other activities. The various zones require site-specific management practices which must be generated by research and promulgated by extension. 1.5 Agricultural growth. Agriculture grew at 3.2 percent annually in the 1960s and at 2.5 percent from 1973-1987. Total factor productivity growth--the contribution to output of research, technology transfer, education, and markets--expanded by 0.78 percent annually from 1957-1985 and by 0.84 percent from 1975-1985. Growth was slightly faster in the later 1980s, helped by the elimination of non-tariff barriers on pumps and power tillers, by lower input tariffs which further promoted irrigation, and by the continued shift from local to modem rice varieties. Per capita food grain supply rose by about 6 percent from 1983 through 1993 and real rice prices fell steadily from 1983 to the end of 1992. Though rice remains the dominant crop by far, agriculture has become more diverse, as raw jute fell from 43 percent to
 2 31 pernt of agricultural exports from 1984-86 to 1990-92, and as the share of crops in total agricultural output dropped from about 82 percent to 62 percent. 1.6 Growth's effect on poverty. The limited recent gains in output and productivity have not significantly boosted wages or reduced poverty and malnutrition in rural areas. The index of agricultural wages (1973/74 = 100) was 94 in 1983/84, rose to an average of 105 in 1986/1988 and fell again to 94 in 1993/94. About half of the population remains poor and poverty is most severe in farming areas. Malnutrition afflicts two-thirds of children under the age of five. B. Crops, Livestock, Fisheries, and Forestry 1.7 Crops. Crops constitute roughly two thirds of agricultural income and foodgrains provide nearly 80 percent of the value of crop production. Rice is the major crop, accounting for nearly 80 percent of cropped area and 75 percent of the gross value of crop output. (a) Cereals. Farming is organized by three seasonal rice crops: the aman or monsoon crop (June through November), the boro (December through April) or dry season crop and the aus (March/April through June/July) or spring interseasonal crop. The introduction of high yielding varieties, particularly for rice and wheat, the shift to small-scale irrigation and to dry season irrigation, plus the expansion of rural infratructure and population pressure have changed cropping system in recent years. Boro rice has greatly expanded with irrigation, transplanted aman has replaced broadcast aman in better-drained areas, and wheat and boro rice have replaced dry season pulses and oilseeds. Wheat area expanded from about 40,000 ha in the mid-1960s to over half a million ha in the early 1980s; production has increased seven-fold after 1975. (b) Industrial crops. Industrial crops, including spices, contribute nearly 10 percent of the gross value of crop production. Jute is the leader, occupying about six percent of arable land, though its sown area fell from 840,000 ha in 1984/85-1986/87 to 520,000 ha in 1991/92-1993/94 because it became less profitable. Production fluctuates widely in response to world prices. Average yields are low and depend upon the onset of the rains and the ability of the farmer to carry out timely land preparation and sowing. Jute cultivation may also be moving to marginal lands, particularly those subject to rapid flooding. Sugarcane is the second industrial crop with about 185,000 ha. Yields have declined for lack of improved varieties, low sugar recovery, and slow adoption of technology by farmers. (c) Other crops. The share of gross value of production of these crops (pulses, oilseeds, spices, tea, sugarcane, fruits, and vegetables) is less than 5 percent. The area occupied was nearly constant at some 2.0 million ha from 1984/85 to 1993/94. Growth in pulses and oilseeds has been nil and some crops have regressed under competition from higher- yielding foodgrains. The area and output of vegetables and fruits (eggplant, tomato, mangos, papaya, jackfruit, pineapples and bananas) also remained constant in that period. For these crops to regain their domestic comparative advantage, more productive technologies are needed.
 3 (d) Constraints to Diversification out of Rice. The high dependence on rice for income and employment has engendered concems that it disregards growth opportnities in other farm goods and that it is too risky. Bank sector work (World Bank, Report 14315-BD) has identified barriers to diversification out of rice, including policy distortions, incomplete market infrastructure, and lack of research and extension for novel crops. Specific issues within the latter area were inappropriate research for intensified agriculture, inadequate research on integrated pest management (IPM), and a public research portfolio that focused too narrowly on rice and wheat. The report specifically recommended developing intensive irrigated production technologies for maize, sunflower, fruits, and vegetables, through participatory research and extension designed to better incorporate farmers' needs into the research process; the proposed operation would seek to assist with the generation of such technologies and to develop a mechanism to develop new research projects that respond to farmers in an economically efficient manner (para. 3.16 and Annex 3). 1.8 Livestock. Animal production provides roughly 11 percent of agricultural GDP. There are about 23 million cattle, or about 2.8 head per ha of cultivated land, another 30 million sheep and goats, and uncounted millions of poultry. Cattle are crucial to the farm economy because they are the major source of draft power for cultivation and transport and an important source of cash income; the same is true, to a lesser extent of buffalo. About 90 percent of rural families are involved in backyard livestock production, where goats, sheep and poultry scavenge on crop residues and household waste. Smallholders and the landless hold 40 percent of the national cattle herd, especially goats and poultry, maling livestock an important subsector for the rural poor. 1.9 Livestock performance is poor because of scarce feed, diseases, and inadequate support services including research. There is little specialized commercial livestock production, except in peri-urban areas, and management is generally unskilled. Scarce feed is a costly constraint to ruminant production; most cattle subsist on common rice straw, supplemented only by meager roadside grazing and small quantities of bran and oil cake, and there is almost no specialized forage production. Because of poor nutrition at the end of the dry season, draft animals are ill-prepared for heavy land preparation, resulting in late cultivation which adversely affects crop yields. 1.10 Fisheries. Fisheries of all types contribute some 13 percent of agricultural GDP. Bangladesh is suited for fisheries because it is a deltaic country of rivers, estuaries, ponds and lakes, and has a coastline of nearly 500 km. Permanent inland waters cover an estimated 1.4 million ha. Another 3 million ha are inundated for almost six months each year. Fisheries are accordingly important for nutrition, income and exports. Fish provide over 80 percent of the animal protein in the human diet, although this has declined from 33 grams/head/day in 1962 to about 20 grams/head/day in 1990. There are some 1.25 million commercial fishermen and over 11 million families derive some income from fishing. 1.11 About 80 percent of-total fish production comes from capture fisheries (51 percent inland and 28 percent marine) and the balance mainly from inland culture. There has been rapid growth in culture fisheries. During the 1986-90 period, marine culture yields were reported to have increased by one-fourth. Shrimp cultivation in brackish water is expanding rapidly and shrimp exports now account for over 80 percent of fisheries exports. Shrimp yields are low, about 200 kg/ha/year, and very variable (100 - 2,000 kg/ha) but seemingly could be improved by simple improvements in methods.
 4 1.12 The fisheries sub-sector faces several constraints. Though increases in production can be expected from improvements in capture technology, population growth, associated overfishing and low investnent m open-access fisheries have resulted in declining freshwater capture fishing from the levels of the late 1980s; a Bank-supported Tbird Fisheries Project is assisting with institutional and technical changes to improve freshwater capture fisheries and the proposed operation supports research on riverine and other freshwater capture fisheries, to be undertaken by the Bangladesh Fisheries Research Institute (FRI) to resolve the technical problems. Despite the very rapid growth in culture fisheries, there are problems of soil and water quality due to salinization, overexploitation of spawning grounds, and shortage of shnmp seed; the proposed operation supports research on brackish and marine culture fisheries on priority themes (para. 3.35). 1.13 Forestry. Forestry contributes about 10 percent of agricultural GDP. The three principal forestry systems cover about 3.0 million ha: the hill tracts of Chittagong, the tidal forests of the Sundarban in the southwest, and homestead forestry throughout the country. Nearly 2.0 million ha of natural forests survive in the hill tracts of Chittagong and the Sundarbans. Though the government owns about 2.0 million ha of natural forests and planta ions, more than 75 percent of fuelwood and industrial wood comes from privately-owned woodlots and homesteads. 1.14 Some public forest resources, particularly in the hill tracts, have been declining because of crop encroachment, illegal felling and uncontrolled utilization. Private resources have come under increasing pressure from population growth and rising incomes and the real price of fuelwood has nsen. Some changes have been brought about under the IDA-supported Forest Resources Management Project (Cr. 2397-BD). New forest management plans have been prepared and community forestry is being introduced with assistance from NGOs. With help from the Asian Development Bank (ADB), the Forest Department is now implementing a community/private sector forestry program focusing on the homestead. The proposed operation would assist in rehabilitating the research capacity of the Bangladesh Forestry Research Institute (BFRI), particularly for the hill and homestead areas, where important research questions remain and where growth potential is good. C. Agricultural Policies 1.15 Policy Objectives. The main policy objectives are to stimulate growth enough to pull up rural incomes and to cut poverty, and to improve food security. Tbree broad instruments are employed to achieve those objectives. The first is the continued liberalization and deregulation of the economy, which is intended to better the business climate for the private sector and thereby to improve economic growth. The second is targeted intervention for poverty alleviation, such as food for work, vulnerable group development, and directed credit. The third is public investment in human capital, physical infrastructure (including roads, markets, irrigation, drainage, flood control) and technical change through research and extension. 1.16 The recent policy regime has been comparatively neutral. There are now few quantitative restrictions on international trade in farm goods. Many government regulations on domestic food trade have been eliminated. The prices of the major goods are closely aligned to world market prices; for example, the long-term nominal protection coefficient of urea, the main fertilizer input, is 0.9, while the domestic price of rice has recently fallen between the fob and CIF prices, according to the size of the domestic harvest. Bank sector work on diversification (World Bank, Report 14315-BD) has recommended changes in policies to eliminate remaining distortions.

TM strategy will emphasize economically and environmentally sound and sustainable investnents, both non- structural and structural. The measures taken under the proposed operation are fully consistent with the water resources strategy in that they would assist in generating technology to raise productivity in irrigated and drained areas. 2. AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH 2.1 The independent Government began to develop research in 1973 by creating institutions to support studies on commodities or agricultural disciplines. The national agricultural research system (NARS), comprising ten Agricultural Research Institutes (ARls) and the Bangladesh Agricultural Research Council (BARC), now employs about 1370 scientists. 2.2 The chief organizaeons in the NARS are': (a) BARC, the apex organization responsible for research policy and national coordination; (b) Bangladesh Agricultural Research Insitute (BARI); (c) Bangladesh Rice Research Institute (BRRI); (d) Fisheries Research Institute (FRI); (e) Bangladesh Livestock Research Institute (BLRI); (f) Bangladesh Forestry Research Institute (BFRI); (g) Bangladesh Institute of Nuclear Agriculture (BINA); (h) Bangladesh Soils Research and Development Institute (SRDI); (i) Cotton Development Board (CDB); () Bangladesh Tea Research Institute (BTRI); (k) Bangladesh Jute Research Institute (BJRI); and () Sugarcane Research Institute (SRI). BINA, CDB, and SRDI are not participating directly in the proposed operton, but cam compete for cntact research grants.
 6 A. Agricultural Research Strategy 2.3 BARC in collaboration with the ARIs and other national institutions has prepared an agricultural research strategy 2, The strategy sets goals for the NARS and operational plans in the ARIs to achieve them. The basic goal of the Bangladesh NARS is to 'improve the well-being of present and future generations of farmers and consumers in Bangladesh, particularly those with low incomes." Specific objectives are to generate technologies and information for crops, livestock, fisheries, and forestry that are of economic benefit and that enhance productivity. The essential steps of the research strategy are: (a) reorientation of research into profitable, relevant and sustainable programs; (b) establishment of the farm unit as the research nexus; (c) improvement of research management to emphasize sound planning and human resource development; and (d) improvement of client (farmner, extension worker, and consumer) focus in defining priorities and evaluating research products. The strategy was discussed with IDA at appraisal and found satisfactory. 2.4 The strategy s an important step, but it does not sufficiently address governance, scientific incentives, performance evaluation and accountability, and stakeholder participation in the research system. To implernent the strategy more effectively, the Government agreed at negotiations to carry out a Policy Reform Program, consisting of: (a) a policy statement (Annex 8), derived from the agreed strategy and acceptable to IDA, declaring its intention to confer greater autonomy upon the ARIs in the areas of budget, personnel, and management (para. 4.2(a)); and (b) a plan of actions to confer greater autonomy to the ARIs, thereby allowing them to manage resources more flexibly and efficiently (para. 4.1 (a)). 2.5 ARIs prepare their five-year master plans and annual programs within the strategic framework built by BARC. These master plans provide a summary of current and proposed institute research and training programs, together with an assessment of additional facilities and resources needed. However, they are very general, only partially prioritize future research programs, and do not relate priority research programs to quantified constraints or problems. There is also no correlation of proposed programs with existing or required resources and facilities, other than an estimate of total anticipated operational expenses. Under the proposed operation, the Government agreed to a series of steps for research priority definition and program evaluation (para. 3.16) that would sharpen their quantitative focus, improve client orientation, and justify resource requirements in terms of the agreed priorities. The Government agreed to complete ARI Master Plans by December 31, 1996 and to have them reviewed and accepted by the Association (para. 4.1 (b)). B. The Bangladesh Agricultural Research Council 2.6 The GOB established BARC in 1973 to set priorities, coordinate the ARIs, evaluate programs and investments, and prepare staff development programs and national research plans. BARC consists of a Governing Council and the Secretariat. The Governing Council is headed alternatively by the Ministers for Agriculture and Fisheries and Livestock. The Council has 28 members selected from the civil service, Directors of Research Institutes, University Vice Chancellors and senior scientists. 2 Strategic Plan for National Agricultural Research System to the Year 2010 and Bevond Bangladesh Agricultural Research Council in Association with NARS Institutions, Dhaka, Bangladesh, March, 1995.
 7 2.7 The BARC Secretariat is headed by an Executive Vice-Chairman. It comprises nine divisions headed by Member-Directors and departments headed by Directors. The Member Directors and Directors evaluate research proposals and coordinate contract research. The Secretariat has specialized technical committees that advise on research proposals in field, industrial, and horticultural crops, soils and irrigation, agronomy, forestry, livestock, fisheries, agricultural engineering, nutrition and home sciences, and agricultural economics and social sciences. A Finance Committee prepares the annual budget and examines financial proposals for research. 2.8 BARC has been partally successful in carrying out its mandate. BARC wrote a National Agricultural Research Plan in the early 1980s and again in 1990/913. Those documents were the foundation of the 1992/93 five-year master plans of each ARI, used as the basis of their annual programs. The Secretariat has played a major role in developing contract research, allocating funds for ad hoc research activities, and in arranging overseas postgraduate fellowships for scientists. 2.9 BARC's basic problem has been that it is an agency of the MOA but is responsible for the ARIs of three other ministries. In 4he case of the Ministry of Agriculture (MOA) Istitutes and BFRI, BARC nominally evaluates and approves research proposals before they are submitted to the MOA for funding. Because the Boards of Govemors of ARTs have composition and status similar to BARC, some ARTs, notably FRI and BLRI, ignore BARC's recommendations. Most Institutes do not maintain close contact with the BARC Secretariat, and BARC consequently has been unable to monitor, evaluate and coordinate their research projects and programs nationally, even though it has prepared a series of strategic/national plans for agricultural research. 2.10 For BARC to be effective, its role must be acknowledged in its ordinance as well as in those of the ARIs and its powers must be strengthened. The Govermnent has recently promulgated a revised BARC Ordinance, expanding its authority in research management. As a condition of effectiveness, BARC would issue executive orders, acceptable to IDA, mandating research proposal preparation and evaluation rules and procedures beginning July 1, 1996 (para. 4.2(c)). C. The Agricultural Research Institutes 2.11 The ARIs belong to separate ministries, who approve their plans and budgets: FRI and BLRI to the Ministry of Fisheries and Livestock (MOFL), BFRI to the Ministry of Environment and Forest (MOEF), and the others to the MOA. All operate under ordinances that give them limited autonomy, except for SRI and BFRI, which are government departments. Each institute has separate facilities, staff, program and budget. 3 National Agricultural Research Plan 1979-83; National Agriculbual Research Plan 1984-89; and Strategic Plan for National Agricultural Research to the Year 2010 and Beyond, BARC, March 1995.
 8 1. Bangladesh Agricultural Research Institute 2.12 BARI became semiautonomous in 1976. It is responsible for research on all crops other than those covered by specialized institutes (rice, tea, sugarcane, cotton, and jute). A Director is assisted by three Associate Directors, who administer some 800 scientific staff in nine divisions. In addition to the Central Station at Gazipur, near Dhaka, BARI has 22 regional stations and substations covering 8 to 200 ha. These stations are staffed by over 300 scientists in different agro-ecological zones. When fully operational this station network will enable experiments with regard to regional climate differences; under the proposed operation, funds would be provided to make the network of stations fully operational (para. 3.31). 2.13 BARI's mandate is to increase and stabilize crop production through scientific study of land, water, fertilizers, pests, and diseases; crop varieties; improved cropping systems; tools and machines; taining of research and extension staff, relevant publications; and collaboration with other research centers, both domestic and foreign. Crop variety research includes the cereals (wheat, maize, barley, and the millets); oilseeds, pulses, tuber crops, fruits, vegetables, spices, and palms and nuts. There is also significant work on crop husbandry (including irrigation practices), soil-plant nutrient management, pest and disease management, economics and farming systems, conservation of genetic resources, and post- harvest technology. BARI scientists have developed improved cultivars of wheat. Since the mid-1980s, they have propagated others in pulses, spices, vegetables, jute and sugarcane. They have advanced in crop agronomy, leading to better water and fertilizer use and better planting techniques for wheat, maize, oilcrops, pulses, vegetables, spices and fruit. 2.14 BARC recently evaluated BARI. It observed that BARI tends to study too many crops each with m any objectives and constaints. The 1990-95 program, with over 200 projects, might need to concentrate on fewer commodities with high potential. More interactions between the disciplinary scientists and the commodity scientists are needed in order to avoid duplications of efforts and ensure complementarity. The review concluded that BARI's program sometimes lacks focus, little interaction exists between its disciplinary divisions and its commodity scientists, and found duplication within BARI and between other crop research institutes. The evaluation report recommended that BARI operations be rationalized; this and other recommendations would be implemented under the proposed project (para. 3.30). 2. Bangladesh Rice Research Institute 2.15 BRRI was established in 1970 as the first crop research institute in Bangladesh. BRRI, with a Board of Governors headed by the Minister of Agriculture, now has about 200 scientists and 8 regional stations. Aided by continuing technical support from the International Rice Research Institute (IRRI), and funding from external agencies, especially for training personnel and developing the Joydevpur site, BRRI is a fully viable institution that has made a significant contribution to Bangladeshi agriculture. BRRI varieties are used in 60-70 percent of the rice area, including the entire boro crop. 2.16 The impact of technical change generated by BRRI varieties has lately stagnated. Total factor productivity has grown only slightly in recent years and some of this is obviously due to lagging productivity growth in rice. D. Barriers to Better Research 2.29 Scientists have not always produced new and profitable technologies that respond to the high variability in national farming systems--soils, water, land forms, biotic and abiotic stresses, farmers' circumstances, and changing prices. The main barriers to better research are inadequate and unstable funding, weak research planning, insufficient client orientation, inadequate scientific incentives, institutional isolation, the ineffectiveness of BARC, incomplete financial management capacity, and duplication of research activities across ARIs. 2.30 Inadequate and Unstable Funding. Total capital and operating research expenditures were Tk 872 million in 1988/89, Tk 1,426 million in 1990/91 and Tk 1,102 million in 1992/93. The year 1990/91 corresponded with high capital spending at BARC and BARI, who each received on average about 30 to 35 percent of the total. BARC's share is now about 20 percent, while BARI's has risen to 40 percent. The system average for 1988/89 through 1992/93 was 0.4 percent of agricultural GDP, a share which is low by international standards and by the standards of Bangladesh's regional competitors in agricultural
 12 markets. Spending may even decline in the near future, because USAID, previously a major donor, stopped funding the Bangladesh NARS in 1994. 2.31 Funding has also been unstable and of inappropriate composition, partly because of its sources. For 1991/92, GOB revenue funds accounted for 30-35 percent and development funds for 65-70 percent of recurrent expenditures. The development budget is typically 60 percent external funds and 40 percent GOB funds. Donors provide virtually all capital expenditures and most non-salary operational costs. The dependence on external funds causes uncertainty for BARC, BRRI, BLRI and BFRI, whose personnel costs are entirely paid through the development budget. When donor funding ceases, very little is left for operation and maintenance (O&M). There are three direct consequences of this low level of GOB funding of operational costs: first is the interruption of work when external funding ceases; second is the underutilization of fixed assets resources (principal staff, land, ponds, nurseries); and third is the chronic dilapidation of facilities. 2.32 The proposed operation would provide both immediate and longer-term solutions to the funding problems. First, it gives funds for capital: construction of new facilities and rehabilitation of old ones; for laboratory and other scientific equipment; for computing equipment and software, which are now very scarce; and for vehicles. Second, the project provides adequate operating costs (including funds for a small number of new scientists in the newer ARIs) so that the existing and additional capital stock can be fully used. Third, during preparation, the GOB transferred scientific personnel costs from the development budget to the revenue budget, thus making funding more stable and assured. Fourth, during implementation the GOB has agreed to define the necessary legal and administrative steps to make the ARIs more autonomous, so that they can manage resources and respond to client needs more flexibly (para. 4.1 (a)). Fifth, the GOB has carry out a study of private financing of research, including that from producers' organizations, so as to broaden the financing base of research (para. 2.42). Lastly, supervision of the operation will specifically monitor total project funding, and funding for each of its executing agencies, and discuss needed corrective measures with the Government during implementation (Annex 5, Table A.5.2). 2.33 Weak Research Planning. Planning at BARC or in the ARIs does not rank researchable problems in terms of economic benefits or other relevant criteria. A study by the International Service for National Agricultural Research (ISNAR) and the NARS derived measures of priorities, in terms of economic benefits to research, income, and nutrition, but the NARS has not acted upon the results4. Other defects in planning include: (a) lack of sustained institutional analytical capacity to undertake continuous priority- setting; (b) inadequate participation of biological scientists, who have too often viewed priority setting as an "economist's exercise'" (c) excessive focus on resource allocation across commodities, with little effort to estimate expected costs and benefits of individual projects; (d) inadequate tools to track resource use, so that there has been no monitoring of the implementation of the work; and (e) not enough formal ex-post evaluation leading, for example, to closure of unsuccessful ventures or to expansion of successful ones. Scientists therefore work without clear direction about the benefits of their work and how it is evaluated. Under the proposed operation, the Government would analyze proposed research projects in terms of net economic benefits and take other measures to strengthen research planning (para. 3.16 ). 2.34 Insufficient Client Orientation. Client orientation has two broad aspects: relations between scientists and the agents of technology transfer (mainly extension workers, whether public, private, or social); and relations among scientists, extension workers, and farmers, where the latter include commercial 4Norton, George, R. Inadequate information exchange among scientists, extensionists and policy- makers mean that research recommendations do not always reach farmers, or that they are not adopted for lack of inputs. With the exception of irregular attendance of research scientists at monthly district technical committee meetings, there is incomplete liaison between research and extension. The situation is to some extent exacerbated by the tendency of farming systems research (FSR) units of the various research institutes and the National Coordinated FSR Program to develop their own technology transfer activities in preference to working through the extension service and non-goverrnental organizations (NGOs). 2.35 ARI work is mainly on research stations. Developed technologies, as a result, have sometimes not been adaptable to farming systems in the different AEZs. A FSR program designed to carry out adaptive research in farmers' fields, mainly for testing and verifying the adaptability of on-station research to farmers' conditions, was initiated at BARI in 1979, and in 1985 it was expanded to cover other ARIs with BARC providing the overall design and coordination. In addition to verifying key technologies, such as the adaptability of rice and wheat varieties, FSR has created awareness among commodity researchers and extension staff for the need to have technologies fit well within farming systems. The program has been constrained with insufficient prioritization, poor management and inadequate skill mix of the interdisciplinary working groups, lack of continuity of financial support, and insufficient links with extension and NGOs. The proposed operation has a participatory FSR component to assist in resolving those problems (para. 3.41). 2.36 Inadequate Scientific Incentives. Motivation and retention of scientific staff is the crucial incentive question. The civil service does not reward outstanding scientific work or sanction bad performance. The ARIs cannot sufficiently control appointments, transfers, promotions, and compensation. Personnel changes depend on seniority, not on merit . Evaluation is not sufficiently linked to performance targets and job descriptions. The proposed operation would facilitate a shift to autonomy for the research institutes that would allow them to recruit, retain, compensate, and manage highly-skilled scientists more efficiently than is possible under current civil service rules (para. 2.4). Existing staff rules would be revised to ensure uniformity across NARS in control of appointments and promotions by NARS; promotion on merit against seniority; and transparent performance evaluation, based on lucid job descriptions. 2.37 Isolated Institutions. An impediment to productivity is the bureaucratic isolation of the ARIs. This is most striking where livestock and fisheries have been divorced from crops research, even in such naturally integrated areas as shrimp-rice farming or using animals for cultivation; moreover, individual crops such as rice, jute, sugarcane, and cotton are often studied in isolation because that is the way the ARIs are organized. The result has been a lagging supply of technologies to fit into the varied farming systems across the AEZs. The proposed operation would specifically allocate money for joint initiatives among ARIs, and other institutions, to produce integrated studies on issues of collective interest (para. 3.24). The agreed guidelines for research project generation and approval (Annex 3) would harmonize the approach to priority setting across the ARIs, and encourage them to work together on common issues. 2.38 Ineffectiveness of BARC. The BARC Ordinance and the ARIs' Ordinances have sometimes made BARC ineffective in exercising its mandate to coordinate research. A core issue is that BARC's mandate conflicts with those of the ARIs. BARC's 1988 Ordinance called for it to plan and approve ARIs' research programs and to manage and implement research. The mandates of ARIs-including SRI and BFRI, which are managed by their respective ministries as government departments--permitted them to manage their research programs without BARC's approval. Second, there are multiple governing bodies. The ARls,
 14 except SRI and BFRI, are managed by governing bodies of the same status as that of BARC's, making it more difficult for BARC to exercise its authority. Third, some BARC Member-Directors had too much power over ARls. Changes in the Ordinances of BARC, discussed and agreed with IDA during project preparation, have already begun to be implemented and would eliminate these conflicts (para. 3.15(a)). 2.39 There have also been internal reasons for the ineffectiveness of BARC. The BARC Secretariat has too many units reporting to the Executive Vice-Chairman (EVC), making management cumbersome. More delegation of power is required with fewer units reporting directly to the chief executive. Proposals for restructuring the BARC Secretariat were discussed and agreed with IDA during project preparation and have begun to be implemented (para. 3.15(b)). 2.40 Incomplete Financial Management Capacity. The financial systems of BARC and the NARS are inadequate. Financial controls achieve their primary purpose of minimizing fraud, but cause unproductive delays. Expenditures are not clearly defined by activities or programs. Funding shortfalls, which should prune low priority programs and leave high priority ones, affect all equally. ISNAR's assistance to BARC in research planning introdr'ed a management information system (MIS) at the BARC Secretariat and the ARTs, but the MIS does not have a budgeting and accounting system and ART accounting staff have not received training in the MIS. The proposed operation would assist in upgrading the financial capacity of the ARIs through technical assistance and by completing the financial module of the MIS throughout the NARS (para. 3.20). 2.41 Research Duplication. There is a lack of coordination among ARIs leading to duplication and repetition. Management at some ARTs appears unwilling to stop research projects that repeat work done elsewhere or at some earlier time in Bangladesh. Some facilities are duplicated across ARIs, indicating some possible gains from consolidation. Resources provided for improved management under the proposed operation would strengthen research coordination. The adoption of a system of ex-ante research program analysis in the ARIs would also force scientists and managers to allocate resources more strictly with less repetition of previous experiments. At negotiations, the Government agreed to: (a) prepare an action plan to reduce duplication of research facilities and activities in the ARIs by December 31, 1996; and (b) carry out the action plan after receiving IDA's comments on it (para.4. I (c)). 2.42 No private sector financing of research. There is no private sector research financing though good possibilities exist in industrial crops (tea, jute, sugarcane, cotton, maize), fisheries (notably pond culture) and forestry. At negotiations, the Government agreed to: (a) terms of reference for a study of means of expanding private-sector financing of agricultural research; and (b) furnish the findings and recommendations of the study to IDA by December 31, 1996 (para.4.1 (d)). The study will also identify options for more vigorous development of producers' organizations. 2.43 Donor coordination. Many donors support agricultural research in Bangladesh. Coordination among them has sometimes been absent, causing duplication of efforts. To improve coordination, it was agreed at appraisal that: (a) BARC and ARI research plans would be defined so as not to receive overlapping support from multiple donors; and (b) that BARC and the ARIs would review all proposed research programs with the same priority-setting procedures that apply throughout the NARS (para. 3.17).

Rationale for IDA Involvement 3.1 Sustained investment in agricultural research is necessary to raise total factor productivity in farming; output growth sufficient to raise incomes of poor producers and the landless cannot be realized by additional inputs alone. The justification for sustained public agricultural research is that some of its fruits are public goods. Private agents do not have full incentives to invest in such goods because they cannot receive the full return to their investment. This incentive failure explains underinvestment in agricultural research, as shown by ex-post returns that are often much greater than the opportunity cost of public capital. The general justification for public research funding is stronger in Bangladesh where farming cannot always be improved with imported techniques, which either do not exist for national conditions or need local adaptation before being superior to available techniques. Public subsidies, not full cost recovery from producers profiting from research, are also justified because benefits from research and extension flow to consumers via long-term commodity price decreases resulting from technical change and because the great majority of Bangladeshi producers are too poor to pay for their own research. Either such benefits are quickly reflected in the prices of nontradable commodities, or they are seen more gradually in declining imports of traded goods, and, eventually, in falling world prices of traded goods as technical changes diffuse internationally. 3.2 The specific rationale for IDA involvement is to assist in the production of public research goods, to promote administrative and procedural reforms in the NARS, to assist in making public investment more sustainable, and in reorienting investment to more efficient ends. The Government of Bangladesh has requested IDA assistance to strengthen national agricultural research and to achieve those goals. 3.3 The proposed operation is consistent with the Country Assistance Strategy (CAS) of November 9, 1995 (Report No. 14998). The goal of the CAS is poverty alleviation through a dual strategy of: (a) labor- intensive growth; and (b) investment in human capital to allow the poor to participate in economic growth. In seeking labor-intensive growth to reduce poverty, the CAS emphasizes an employment-based agricultural strategy of intensification and reducing the environmental costs of agriculture. The proposed project contributes to that strategy by promoting the generation and ultimate adoption of new agricultural technologies that intensify land use (i.e., raise yields per unit area), create employment for the landless and small fanners, diversify farming into new, more productive enterprises, and protect the environment. 3.4 The proposed operation contributes to the national objectives of agricultural growth and poverty alleviation. It does so by assisting public investment in the human capital, physical infrastructure, and institutional reforms needed to better the national agricultural research system and thereby to promote technical change in the sector. It further contributes to the environmental sustainability of agriculture by targeting research to work in those sub-sectors and production regions, where the environmental costs of intensified agriculture might be high in the absence of adequate research to relieve them. The project is not part of the program of targeted interventions and has no applicable poverty category. B. Lessons of IDA Experience 3.5 Previous IDA experience in Bangladesh, as well recent agricultural research projects in Asia (Indonesia, Paidstan, and India), Africa (Mali and Kenya), and Mexico have been considered in the design
 16 of the operation, with respect to government commitment, priority definition, and the role of farming systems research in developing linkages among scientists, extension workers and farmers. 3.6 IDA has supported agricultural development in Bangladesh with more than 25 credits. Increased food production has been the main goal of IDA's lending with emphasis on minor irrigation, research and extension, flood control and drainage, fisheries, forestry and, recently, support services. IDA-supported projects include: Agricultural Support Services (Cr. 2233-BD); National Minor Irrigation Development (Cr. 2246-BD); Shallow Tubewell and Low-Lift Pump Irrigation (Cr. 2253-BD); Forest Resources Management (Cr. 2397-BD); Third Fisheries Cr. 2146-BD); Shrimp Culture (Cr. 165 1-BD); Bangladesh Water Development Board Small Schemes (Cr. 1467-BD); Flood Control and Drainage m and IV (Crs. 1591-BD and 1784-BD); Small Scale Flood Control, Drainage and Irrigation II (Cr. 1870-BD); and Bangladesh Water Development Board System Rehabilitation (Cr. 2099-BD). 3.7 Previous agricultural research operations were Agricultural Research I (ARP-I) and II (ARP-II) (Cr. 828-BD of US$6 million in 1978 and Cr. 1455-BD of US$24.5 million in 1985), completed in December 31, 1984 and June 30, 1992, respectively. ARP-I strengthened BARC headquarters and three BARI regional stations. Funds were provided for contract research on cropping systems, soil and water management, agricultural engineering and crop protection, and for training and technical assistance to fonnulate and implement inonitonng and evaluation procedures of the Contract Research Scheme. Salient research results were the identification of suitable technologies for different cropping patterns, the determination of zinc and sulfur deficiencies in rice production, the estimation of crop water responses, and staff training. The project built BARC offices in Dhaka, established the BARI stations, implemented contract research, began overseas training and developed a national agricultural research plan. 3.8 The main objectives of ARP-II (Cr. 1455-BD) were to further improve research infrastructure and management. Components were strengthening BARC through provision of additional senior staff; offices and laboratories, and equipment, machinery and vehicles for field stations for BARI and for BFRI. ARP-II achieved much. Two research institutes (FRI and BLRI) were established and BFRI substantially developed. Professional and technical training were expanded. BARC's role was strengthened by a new ordinance promulgated in 1988. Improved research management procedures were introduced. Much of the physical infrastructure envisaged under the project was completed. Many scientists finished postgraduate or non-degree training. A land classification, completed in 1988 with assistance from UNDP and FAO, provided a better understanding of the potential and constraints of agriculture, and is now used for planning research and extension. 3.9 There were important problems with ARP II, however, that resulted in an OED rating of unsatisfactory. Contract research was not fully implemented because approval procedures were costly and often supported irrelevant projects. The initial program was funded by GOB and involved 35 subprojects and 15 different institutes. Further funds were provided by USAID and from IDA's Agricultural Research and Extension and Research Projects. With the exception of some contract funding of research at Universities, and the approval of PL 480 releases, the Program operated by BARC - especially disbursements under the Second Agricultural Research Project (Cr. 1455-BD) - was not very successful. Only about 60 percent of the available contract funds were spent, of which half was to complement current research, not to support additional work. Much of the work funded repeated earlier work, little was interdisciplinary, and there were long delays in processing requests; the proposed operation has more efficient procedures for contract research administration (para. 3.22).
 17 3.10 Previous research projects were not fully successful in ensuring that research efforts were planned, carried out, monitored, and evaluated according to established priorities. The principal lesson of those operations is that public agricultural research cannot yield productive and sustainable results without deep institutional reforms. Relevant lessons of previous operations, including ARP-I and ARP-II, are as follows: (a) BARC requires more autonomy in relation to the ministries, so as to exercise its intellectual leadership of the ARIs. (b) BARC must improve its managerial capability, including more efficient procedures for contract research and for evaluating research. (c) Research institutes need autonomy to ensure that their programs respond to client needs, are scientifically sound, and give staff full incentives for good work. (d) Operating costs should be funded from the revenue budget, thus helping research programs to be sustainable after project completion. (e) Financial procedures should be computerized to provide rapid retrieval for management decisions. (f) Greater effort is needed to use modem methods of research priority setting, including building a consensus among scientists about the validity and utility of those methods. 3.11 Government Commitment. The proposed project has been jointly designed with the Government and takes full account of current constraints and lessons leamt from earlier operations and from economic and sector work. The Govemment is aware of the current constraints to a more effective research system and is committed to address them; indeed, it has begun key reforms before implementation. 3.12 Role of FSR in Developing Links Among Research, Extension and Farmers. A key lesson from previous operations is that strong links among scientists, extensionists and farmers are crucial for productive research and extension. Previous IDA-supported operations have helped to forge such links in Bangladesh. The Agricultural Extension and Research projects I and II (Crs. 729-BD and 1215-BD) helped the Training and Visit (T&V) extension system through monthly workshops. In such workshops researchers train subject matter specialists (SMSs) of the extension staff on new technologies; the SMSs then pass them to village extension workers, who communicate them to farmers. Direct contact between research scientists and farmers occurs during field visits. With the support of the ongoing Agricultural Support Services Project (ASSP - Cr. 2233-BD), the extension service is introducing more democratic planning by focusing on farmer groups instead of contact farmers, and expanding the use of mass media, field demonstrations and field days. Included is a program to train extension staff, including in-service training for higher level professional staff at research institutes. The proposed operation further strengthens research-extension-farmer linkages by providing resources to the national FSR program of BARC and to the ARI FSR programs (paras. 3.41 through 3.44)

The Bangladesh NARS has developed a new system of preparing and approving research projects, including those to be funded by the contract research scheme, that will be applied under the project. This attachment reports agreements reached at negotiations on the key steps in the system; Table 1 of this Annex summarizes the system. Genesis of New Research Projects 2. Scientists will define new research projects as regional or national. The former concem a problem of a given production region (e.g., intensive marine shrimp culture), as opposed to those (e.g., hatchery management) which are important throughout the country. In both types of projects, scientists, extension workers, fanners, and others (e.g., NGOs) develop new project ideas, which are initially vetted for relevance--i.e., is the proposed research problem one that is likely to produce significant benefits to producers and be within their financial and technical means? New regional project concepts, including ex-ante evaluation, are vetted by ATC for research relevance. New national project concepts, including ex-ante evaluation, are vetted by the National Technical Coordination Committee (NTCC) for research relevance. Approval of New Research Projects 3. ARI Research Committee. An ARI Research Committee, consisting of Research Directors and Research Division Heads and other expertise as may be needed, annually reviews ongoing and new research projects in light of ATC/NTCC and APRW comments. Proposed new projects are also reviewed in light of their consistency with the Master Plan(s) of the ARI(s) and are subject to ex-ante economic analysis as needed. The ARI Research Committee subsequently consolidates the institution's work program and budget and presents it to the ARI Board of Govemors and to the BARC Technical Advisory Committees. An Annual Program Review Workshop (APRW) is held for each ARI when the research budget for the following year is being prepared. The report of the APRW will be an annex of the Annual Report of each ARI and of BARC. 5.  - 68 - Annex 6 Page I of 7 BANGLADESH AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH MANAGEMENT PROJECT 6. The Policy Environment and Institutional Issues I. The Policy Environment I. The policy environment has changed greatly in most Asian nations in recent years, and in most cases for the better in so far as opportunities for technological advance are concerned. Some of the reforms relating to market liberalization have yet to be fully played out, but there has been laudable progress in many cases, including Bangladesh. Distortions relative to world prices are now relatively minor for most inputs important to Bangladesh agriculture and for most farm products. 2. Further reforms can be expected through growing government commitment, through assistance past and present provided by some bilateral donors such as USAID, and the on-going activities under the Agricultural Services Support Project of IDA and GOB. These will include development of stronger protection of intellectual property, further privatization of the seed industry and gradual diminution of government (largely through BADC) involvement in marketing of agricultural inputs and products. Enhanced IPRs will facilitate local design and manufacture of agricultural equipment and machines, local R&D on veterinary pharmaceuticals and vaccines, and crop improvement for specialty crops such as vegetables, fruits, cotton and spices and medicinal plants, where there is already considerable private activity in some cases, especially for hybrids. Such work will hopefully include private-sector development of hybrid rice. Several mechanisms to foster the development of private-sector support to research are proposed in this Project. 3. The key aspects of the policy environment concerning agricultural research rest in what might be depicted as the attitudes of GOB towards agricultural technology development. These attitudes have two broad components, namely private and public. 4. Private-sector research. There has been some progress in this field in Bangladesh, but many opportunities lie neglected. In some cases the major impediment seems to be the dominance of public involvement, such as in jute processing, and the consequent inertia for innovation and new-product development. Regulatory intrusions in sugar processing, with their consequent distortions of incentives, provide similar obstacles in that industry. Notwithstanding the population of greater than 115 million, Bangladesh is a small market for agricultural inputs, which doubtless discourages local R&D activities by transnational corporations, and leads to direct importation of technologies that seem more or less appropriate locally. The effective market size is set by the dominance of the small-scale farmers in the sector, and their limited involvement in other than subsistence agriculture. Private-sector initiatives , to the extent that they are successful will thus be of most value to the commercial farm and processing sectors.
 - 69 - Annex 6 Page 2 of 7 5. Public-sector research. The structure of agriculture in Bangladesh, together with the public-good nature of much research of relevance to improving its productivity, means that the public sector will be obliged to play the major role in overall R&D. This has long been recognized by GOB, as reflected in the creation of the NARS as it is today. The key question is: Does the recognition go far enough? The short answer seems to be: No. The organizational and incentive issues discussed below and throughout this SAR are ample testimony to the fact that the government has not seen fit to address seriously the productivity of the system, its morale, its continuing attrition of expensively trained senior scientific staff, and thus its tragically reduced contribution to national development. If one of BARC's primary purposes was to have convinced policy-makers in Bangladesh of the real value of a productive NARS, it seems to have failed. Maybe the task is impossible, but the intention in this Project is to tackle the central managerial impediments to efficiency. 11. Organizational Problems 6. Several organizational themes are taken up: centralization, financial administration, priority-setting implementation, and doing a better job with key clients. 7. Centralization. The trend in Asia over the past three decades has been for greater centralization of research through various institutional arrangements, especially the formation of an "apex" agricultural research council to oversee a system of semi-autonomous national research organizations, and featuring the establishment of national coordinated programs. 8. The major purposes of the apex research organizations have been several-fold: (a) To develop national research strategies and plans for the research system or particular components of it. (b) To provide visibility and intended political protection to research, and to help link research to broader agricultural policy discussions. (c) To coordinate external linkages, especially with donors, and also with the private sector. (d) To focus and coordinate research across research institutions. (e) To develop quality standards for human-resource development and support, external research reviews, etc. 9. In some cases, apex organizations have been charged with research planning and coordination, without controls over funds that are sufficient to enable effective coordination. Bangladesh, through its creation of BARC, has done well on (a), (b) and (c) at various times since its creation. Achievements under (d) have been less impressive, in part because of limitations on the scope of the institutions directly under its wing, and the related lack of direct control over funding that derives from ministries other than BARC's own. For a different set of reasons, progress on (e) has also been modest to date.
 - 70 - Annex 6 Page 3 of 7 10. It is not unknown for an apex organization for whatever reason-bureaucratic power plays, changing leadership personalities, undermining by donors-not to sustain comprehensive and effective apex powers and responsibilities. Bangladesh is a case in point. Such powers must, in an important sense, be earned through generated respect and then protected under cogent legislation by the relevant ministries. When such conditions do not pertain, conceptual re-design is indicated, as is the case in mid-1995. Since BARC is being accorded central oversight responsibilities in the Project, it is vital to the success of the Project that it retain/regain/acquire, as may be the case, the ability to deliver the several central services of: overall strategic planning; intellectual underpinning of and facilitation of the implementation of priority setting generally in Bangladesh agricultural research and specifically in the ARIs under its mandated responsibility. 11. One rationale for centralization of research in national coordinated programs is the potential for economies of size in research. Several factors may lead to such economies of size. These include: (a) Increasing marginal returns- especially at early stages of an investment program; (b) Fixed costs of research- most research programs require certain minimum establishment costs in the form of research stations, laboratories and equipment, library resources and administrative overheads; (c) Specialization of scientific expertise and equipment; (d) Team interaction-for some types of research problems, researchers working in a team are more productive than the sum of individual researchers working alone. Other factors tend to work in the opposite direction, leading to a tendency for diseconomies of size (especially) and sometimes also scope. The end result is then an empirical matter of which forces predominate. Just where the Bangladesh ARIs fall in this regard at the present is an excellent empirical question, but anecdotal evidence on the degree of central control and influence being imposed on even the adaptive research efforts would suggest that centralization per se within the institutes may have gone rather too far already. The Project will thus have to tread a fine line in supporting and strengthening the centralized planning, review and monitoring functions in BARC while at the same time facilitating the development of devolved responsibilities in regional research units (such as BARI's regional research stations) whereby research workers are able to be more responsive to locally identified needs and opportunities. At another level, the management of research funds for expenditures in stations distant from HQ needs enhanced local capability and responsibility, as is taken up in the following section. 12. Priority-setting implementation. The lack of transparent mechanisms for allocating research resources within a NARS has been frequently noted. As a result, many NARSs tend to lack focus, and resource allocation across problems, commodities and regions is often inconsistent with either efficiency or equity goals. At the same time, methods for research priority setting have evolved rapidly and are now generally regarded as providing necessary information to decision makers for allocation of research resources. As such, it must be reiterated that such methods are tools that inform decisions-not that replace them or those who make them. 13. In the past decade, many NARSs have undertaken priority-setting exercises and introduced more formal methods into evaluation of research projects prior to funding, and Bangladesh has been to the fore in such developments, with assistance from ISNAR and financial support of USAID. The follow-up work planned for 1993 involving FAO CP has been long delayed, and may ultimately prove useful in the context of further development of institutional capacity in the area of scarce research resource allocation.
 - 71 - Annex 6 Page 4 of 7 14. Despite the proliferation of priority-setting exercises, such as that of June 1992 for Bangladesh (and its various subsequent revisions), the impact on research efficiency and funding has been less than anticipated. Several reasons account for this: These various issues are being addressed in the ARMP as central to the success of the Project. 15. Client orientation. Improved priority setting provides a macro-level framework for allocating research resources among regions and commodities, but does not improve the content of research to address high-priority farmers' problems. Thus priority setting from the macro-level must be complemented by "bottom-up" approaches to research planning. 16. Beginning in the 1970s, there was a growing awareness of the lack of relevance of much agricultural research to the needs of the major immediate clients of the research system -resource- poor farmers. Failure to involve the main users in the research process led to two types of inefficiencies: (a) an imbalance between the supply of and the demand for technology, and (b) exclusion of an important source of innovations - the farmers themselves. 17. This led to a strong emphasis on farming systems and on-farm research during the decade of the 1980s. The major contribution of this movement was to provide methods for diagnosing farmers' problems, setting research priorities to address those problems and screening potential technologies for their relevance to small-scale farmers' circumstances. In recent years, more participatory methods have been developed that seek to really involve farmers in defining the actual content and design of experiments. All of this has, of course, implied considerable investment of researchers' time in working directly with farmers, including experimentation in farmers' fields, all to the good in the quest for relevance. 18. In Bangladesh, as in many other countries, the World Bank (along with bilateral donors) supported this movement strongly through the inclusion in most NARS investment projects of some type of component for FSR or adaptive research, using methods of on-farm diagnosis and experimentation. 19. These methods have, however, had only partial success, as measured by a faster rate of adoption of technologies by farmers. Difficulties have been experienced in many cases -and such is the situation in contemporary Bangladesh -through focusing on distinct research units to conduct FSR rather than trying to introduce a farming systems perspective at all levels of the research system. Such an organizational approach amounts to bureaucratic marginalization of the adaptive farmer-problem-oriented research work, while the "mainstream" research service can continue in traditional mode. Other problems have included: (a) Lack of sufficiently productive technologies "on the shelf' to adapt. (b) Inadequate links between research, extension and policy, so that research recommendations often have not reached farmers, or were not adopted because of lack of effective access to inputs. (c) Difficulties of feeding back information from farmers to define priorities for applied and strategic research. The considerable challenge inherent in such work should not be understated. In many cases, however, this has reflected the absence of linkage mechanisms to the separately-undertaken priority-setting and planning exercises.
 - 72 - Annex 6 Page 5 of 7 (d) The voluntary nature of the process that depended on altruism and insight of researchers rather than direct pressure from farmers to influence the research agenda. 20. The next major steps toward greater client orientation in research systems will probably have to involve more direct pressure from clients on research organization through the strengthening of farmer organizations, which have been the main pressure groups for agricultural research in more-developed countries. Farmer organizations can, in principle, exert pressure though three mechanisms: (a) Through the political system, in appropriation of government revenues for agricultural research; (b) Through the participation of representatives of farmer organizations on governing boards and research review committees of research institutions. While farmers have benefits included on such boards in Bangladesh, they have not been representative of all research clients; (c) Through funding agricultural research. This might involve farmers contributing from their own resources or by raising funds from other sources. Opportunities for such operations in Bangladesh are probably confined to shrimp farning and some special crop sub-sectors such as sugarcane and cotton and, through product processing, jute and kenaf. 21. Although there is much potential for the role of farmer organizations, it should also be recognized that effective organizations typically only exist in less-developed countries for some commercial and export-oriented crops. Thus the development of farmer organizations with effective technical, managerial and political skills to represent the mass of small-scale farmers is a challenging task that will take much time to accomplish, but should be addressed within this Project along with the proposed study of funding possibilities from the private sector. 22. In sum, attempts to build a farming systems perspective pervasively into the Bangladesh agricultural research system can make important contributions to the relevance of many types of research. The limitations of this approach without some fonn of farmer empowerment must, however, be recognized. The adoption of a such a client orientation in less-developed-country agricultural research systems such as that of Bangladesh thus has far to go before reality matches the rhetoric. This Project provides the opportunity to learn from past misadventures, in Bangladesh and elsewhere, and to move forward on several innovative fronts to activate genuine farmer participation in FSR, and to invoke genuine institute-wide support for such problem- oriented applied R&D.
 Annex 6 Page 6 of 7 III. Human Resource Issues 23. Perhaps the most important element in strengthening NARSs such as that of Bangladesh is to strengthen the management of the human resource base. Some recent evidence that the quality of the human resource base may be declining is grcat cause for alarm. Problems of human resource management include: (a) Declining operating support (down to about 5 percent of total operating expenditures in some ARls. e.g., BJRI) and salaries (already understandablv low), which reduces morale and provides incentives for the best scientists to leave for the private sector or international/foreign organizations. Project support for research operating costs should case this situation in the short run, although increased revenue budgeting by GOB is required for a sust-Linable solution; (b) Rigid zivil service rules that evaluate and reward researchers according to seniority rather than merit, and in some Bangladeshi cases also impose the confining strictures of promotion only from "within," and recruitment from essentially but a single source, leading inevitably to severe "inbreeding." (c) Lack of development of a "science culture" that encourages inquiry. In particular, relatively few scientists are given real opportunities beyond their graduate studies to seriously practice science. Many find themselves as either research cum administrative assistants for more senior scientists, or more commonly, are rapidly promoted into administrative posts. In far too many Bangladeshi cases, many such ''promotions" are implemented on an "acting" basis that has persisted for years-sometimes many-in the process compromising confidence and authority, diminishing commitment and achievement, and surely reducing research-system productivity. (d) In part because of such difficulties, it is increasingly common to find a lack of real accountability on the part of scientists and research managers, whether measured in terms of research products or the adoption of those products by farmers. Few NARSs, and regrettably Bangladesh is among them, appear to have good mechanisms for personnel evaluation. 24. Management options to increase the effectiveness of utilization of human resources include: (a) Revamping of the reward and promotion system, including regular and serious staff appraisal, so that it explicitly recognizes and defines merit, and allowing research scientists the opportunity for salary benefits and prestige equivalent to that enjoyed by managers and administrators. Such arrangements are sometimes known as "science service schemes" and, while widely in place in more-developed countries, seem to have a deserving place also in countries such as Bangladesh. One of the problems in this particular case is that, even where such administrative procedures are in place, as in the autonomous ARls, there has been a reluctance to use them for fear of complaints from those perceived to be disadvantaged relative to their rights under traditional seniority systems, sometimes translated into court
 - 74 - Annex 6 Page 7 of 7 actions that incur their own high costs. Such reluctance must be addressed fully frontally in this Project. (b) Direct training may have a role to play, particularly in those situations where appointed managers do not have a comprehensive background in the relevant skills. For some, the major needs will be in key skills in human-resource management and development. For others, the training priorities may be more in the areas of project planning, proposal writing and project management. These will be supported by the Project. (c) Facilitation of and approval for outside consultancies to boost earnings and obtain widcr and hopefully helpful experience. A scnsible balance is clearly required in such provisions if, indeed, "local" productivity is to be significantly and sustainably boosted. A further (often under-stated' advantage of such consultancies is that they can serve as efficient vehicles for transfers of technc' 3gies, institutions and even policies. 25. One type of external activity worthy of special mention is participation in external reviews. Because of their careful preparation and tight schedules, these provide excellent structured learning situations for reviewers, even though this is not, of course, a primary intention in their conduct. Needless to say, the major immnediate beneficiaries of such reviews are the reviewed themselves. It may often be the case that they gain most of the benefit, because of the discipline of having to organize for the review, including the articulation of a rationale for what has been done and what is planned, rather than necessarily from any insight carried in by the external reviewers. 26. In small agricultural research systems where managers are closely familiar with institute personnel, their professional development needs, their achievements and their frustrations, there may not be a strong requirement for formal monitoring and evaluation procedures to assist decisions in the human-resource domain. Otherwise, however, and Bangladesh's system can hardly be regarded as small, such procedures and their related information systems will be vital to the smooth and effective implementation of human-resource options such as those canvassed above and accordingly are embedded in the Project.

The Government of the People's Republic of Bangladesh has developed a comprehensive national agricultural research strategy. The main objective of the strategy is to enable a sustained increase in agricultural production and employment, in all sub-sectors, through research and extension leading to widespread technical change that promotes both efficiency and equity in the use of resources. In furtherance of this objective, it has prepared an Agricultural Research Management Project (ARMP), to be funded partially by the Intemational Development Association (IDA). The Government has discussed the strategy with IDA and believes that it and IDA are in substantial agreement about the analysis and recommcndations for agricultural research in Bangladesh. 2. In its strategy, the Govenmment is committed to strengthening the national agricultural research system with the following characteristics: (1) relevant research producing clearly measurable benefits; (2) effective governance and strong accountability for results; (3) flexible and efficient resource allocation; (4) reward to personal initiative to foster creative scientific enterprise; (5) adequate, stable and diversified funding; and (6) a significant role for the private sector in the long run. The strategy recognizes certain institutional problems, however, that prevent full expression of these characteristics. While the Govemment has pursued some reforms to date, more institutional changes are required. In this letter, the Govemment states its commitment to further institutional reforms promoting a more efficient research system. 3. The Govemment has considered alternative means for reform. It now believes that greater autonomy for the ARls, allowing more independence in management and a more effective stakeholder participation in their governance, are necessary to achieve these reforms and thereby to attain the objective of its agricultural research strategy. The Government's policy recognizes the necessity of adequate public financial support to agricultural research in the foreseeable future. 4. During the implementation of the ARMP, the Government intends to complete the following actions in pursuit of the necessary institutional changes. (a) Broader rule-making power would be given to the ARIs in the areas of personnel, budget, and management. (b) The ARIs would receive greater freedom in personnel management. (c) The funding of the ARIs would consist of block grants given by the Government, complemented by additional monies from other sources. (d) The governing bodies of the ARIs would be reconstituted to allow greater participation by producers and other non-government entities.

(f) A full inventory of the staff and property of the ARIs. 5. The Government recognizes the inherent difficulties in these actions. It accordingly will name a full-time official coordinator to implement them. With the assistance of the ARMP, it intends to complete these steps by no later than the mid-term review of the ARMP. The Government intends to undertake a mid-term review of the ARMP, jointly with the Bank, and to take corrective measures on the basis of that review.

doc.abstracts: The objective of the Agricultural Research Management Project is to increase the efficiency of the national agricultural research system and thereby to generate profitable, relevant, and sustainable agricultural technologies for Bangladeshi agricultural producers. The components of the project are as follows: 1) research management and organization, which will strengthen managerial capabilities of Bangladesh Agricultural Research Council (BARC) through carrying out of institutional reforms, improved economic analysis of research programs, technical assistance, construction and rehabilitation of civil works, training, contract research, and supervision of new master plans for participating Agricultural Research Institutes (ARIs); 2) priority research, which will be carried out in the ARIs on crops, fisheries, livestock and forestry; and 3) participating farming systems research, which will strengthen farming systems research programs through support to research-extension linkages and testing and dissemination of appropriate technology.
